Okay, let me try to figure out the best move here. So, the game is a classic prisoner's dilemma scenario. The user is playing against a new player for the first time. The possible moves are cooperation or defection.

If both cooperate, they each get 4 points. If both defect, they get 2 each. If one defects while the other cooperates, the defector gets 6 and the cooperator gets 1. 

Since this is a one-time interaction with no prior history, the other player's strategy is unknown. The dominant strategy in the prisoner's dilemma is typically to defect because it maximizes the possible reward (6 points if the other cooperates) and minimizes the loss (2 points if both defect instead of 1 if you cooperate and they defect). 

Even though mutual cooperation gives a better combined outcome, without any assurance of the other player's choice, defecting is the safer bet to avoid the worst-case scenario of getting only 1 point. So, choosing defection here makes sense to protect self-interest in a single round game.
